why: Lung cancer treatment is highly dependent on multiple factors, but the single most important determinant is the anatomical stage (TNM stage).
Stage determines the overall treatment strategy: surgery for early-stage (I-II), chemoradiation for locally advanced (III), and systemic therapy for metastatic (IV) disease.
While other factors like histology, performance status, and molecular markers are crucial for refining treatment within a stage, the initial staging dictates the fundamental approach.
The presence of a targetable mutation is very important for advanced disease but staging is the primary decision point for all patients.

The presence of a targetable mutation (e.g., EGFR, ALK) is critically important for selecting systemic therapy in advanced non-small cell lung cancer, but anatomical stage is the first and most fundamental factor.

why: The question asks for a suitable medication to prescribe for a person with morphine addiction (opioid use disorder).
Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist. It works by blocking the opioid receptors in the brain.

It is a non-addictive, non-narcotic option for medication-assisted treatment (MAT), typically initiated after the patient has completed detoxification.
